message.content: This question requires knowledge about how the changing seasons can affect the amount of daylight we experience. As fall approaches, the amount of daylight gradually decreases. Therefore, the light in the evening will end sooner. Option (A) is incorrect because "glow longer" implies that the evening light would last for a longer duration, which is not the case. Option (C) and Option (D) both imply that the light will last longer, which is not accurate during the fall season.

This question requires an understanding of the changing seasons and how they affect daylight hours. As fall approaches, the days gradually get shorter and the nights get longer. Therefore, the light in the evening will end sooner as fall approaches. Option (A) is incorrect because "glow longer" suggests a longer period of daylight, which is not true in this case. Option (C) and (D) are incorrect because they both suggest a longer duration of light, which is not the case as fall approaches.

As fall approaches, the days become shorter, which means that light in the evening will end sooner. Option (C) and (D) are incorrect because they suggest that the light in the evening will last longer or stay later, which is not the case as fall approaches.

Option (D) is incorrect because "stay later" implies that the light would remain present for a longer duration, which is not the case.
